results.headline: Horrors Come Along for the Trip
results.summary_short: In “The Happy House,” a young urban couple take a vacation in the country, with the ensuing terrors becoming symbolic of everything that’s wrong between them.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of The Happy House

results.headline: Celebrating Conspicuous Consumption
results.summary_short: In “Scatter My Ashes at Bergdorf’s,” stars dutifully pay tribute to Bergdorf Goodman, the high-end Manhattan department store.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Scatter My Ashes at Bergdorf's

results.headline: Drama, Uninvited, Is in the Wedding Party
results.summary_short: A wedding is at the center of “Love Is All You Need,” a romantic comedy starring Pierce Brosnan.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Love is All You Need

results.headline: Even Vegan Vampires Can’t Hold Out
results.summary_short: “Kiss of the Damned,” directed by Xan Cassavetes, introduces a strain of vampires who try to swear off humans and drink only blood substitutes.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Kiss of the Damned

results.headline: Bang, Boom: Terrorism as a Game
results.summary_short: “Iron Man 3,” with all its explosions so soon after the Boston Marathon bombings, underscores just how thoroughly terrorism and its aftermath have been colonized by the movies.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Iron Man 3

results.headline: Blood Ties That Don’t Quite Bind
results.summary_short: Daniel Algrant’s “Greetings From Tim Buckley” is a biopic about two musicians who died young: the folk singer Tim Buckley and his folk-rocker son, Jeff Buckley.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Greetings From Tim Buckley

results.headline: To Do: Wander Aimlessly
results.summary_short: The title of “generation Um ...” captures the disenchantment of post-slacker New York anti-achievers.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Generation Um...

results.headline: Agony Eased by a Gentle Art
results.summary_short: “Free the Mind,” a documentary directed by Phie Ambo, explores how meditation and exercises can be used to alleviate post-traumatic stress.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Free the Mind

results.headline: Testing the Strength of a Magic Wand
results.summary_short: In “Desperate Acts of Magic,” two magicians flirt with romance and with joining forces in a show, but complications follow on both fronts.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Desperate Acts of Magic

results.headline: Plenty of Dust, Bullets and Relationship Drama
results.summary_short: In “Dead Man’s Burden,” a woman and her husband wring a living from her family’s parched homestead, watched over by the accumulating graves of her unlucky kin.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Dead Man's Burden

results.headline: An Intervention That Goes Awry
results.summary_short: In “Caroline and Jackie,” a surprise birthday party starts an eventful evening that includes ugly confrontations.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Caroline and Jackie

results.headline: Sex Stars as People, With Dreams and Worries
results.summary_short: “Aroused,” a documentary directed by Deborah Anderson, sets out to humanize female pornography stars.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Aroused

results.headline: It’s Tough to Keep a Tune, but Easy to Fall in Love
results.summary_short: Mozart’s comic opera “Così Fan Tutte” inspires a subplot in the movie “1st Night,” directed by Christopher Menaul.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of 1st Night

results.headline: Emotional Tugs, Real and Fictional
results.summary_short: In “Memories Look at Me,” the director and star, Song Fang, travels from Beijing to Nanjing, China, to visit her parents.

results.headline: Revisiting a Rossellini Classic to Find Resonances of Today
results.summary_short: “Voyage to Italy,” with Ingrid Bergman and George Sanders, finally gets its New York Times review 58 years after its American release.

results.headline: Juggling Primal Conflicts of Innocence and Sin
results.summary_short: “Post Tenebras Lux,” by the Mexican director Carlos Reygadas, is a deeply personal exploration of good and evil.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Post Tenebras Lux

results.headline: How Commune Became Cult
results.summary_short: “The Source Family” looks back at a Hollywood cult from the 1970s led by a professed guru and suspected bank robber.

results.headline: Space Camp — the Style, Not the Place
results.summary_short: B-movie elements galore get their moments in the campy “Ghastly Love of Johnny X.”

results.headline: Sweaty Young Lovers on the Run
results.summary_short: Young lovers travel a hellish road in Central Florida in “Sun Don’t Shine,” from the “Tiny Furniture” actress Amy Seimetz.

results.headline: Hiding From Trouble, Found by Innocents
results.summary_short: In Jeff Nichols’s third feature, two Arkansas boys discover a boat on an overgrown island in the Mississippi River, and also discover the leathery loner who inhabits it.
